editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it was lately acted by the company of the revels.
London, printed by B. A. for Thomas Jones, and are to be sold at his shop in Chancery-lane, over-against the rolls, and in Westminster hall.

div.head: To my honoured friend, master Thomas may, upon his comedy, the heir.
div.l: The heir being born, was in his tender age
Rocked in the cradle of a private stage,
Where lifted up by many a willing hand,
The child doth from the first day fairly stand,
Since, having gathered strength, he dares prefer
His steps into the public theater
The world: where he despairs not but to find
A doom from men more able, but less kind.
I but his usher am, yet if my word
May pass, I dare be bound he will afford
Things must deserve a welcome, it well known
Such as best writers would have wished their own.
You shall observe his words in order meet,
And often stealing on, with equal feet
Slide into equal numbers, with such grace
As each word had been moulded for that place.
You shall perceive an amorous passion, spun
Into so smooth a web, as had the sun,
When he pursued the swiftly flying maid,
Courted her in such language she had stayed,
A love so well expressed must be the same,
The author felt himself from his fair flame.
The whole plot doth like itself disclose
Through the five acts, as doth a look, that goes
With letters, for till every one be known,
The lock's as fast as if you had found none.
And where his sportive muse doth draw a thread
Of mirth, chaste matrons may not blush to read.
〈◊〉 have I thought it fitter to reveal
〈◊〉 want of art (Dear friend) then to conceal
〈…〉 it did appear I did not mean
〈…〉 thy well-wrought comic-scene,
〈…〉 might judge my 〈◊〉 rather to be,
〈…〉 myself, th●● give it thee;
〈…〉 thee none but what thou hast
〈…〉 ▪ and what must my faint breath outlast.
〈…〉 this garment (Though 〈…〉 be
〈…〉 measure) only made for thee,
〈…〉 to 〈◊〉, 'tis cause the stuff
〈…〉 allowed me, was not large enough.

div.head: An excellent comedy called the heir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Roscio.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Hast thou divulged the news
That my son died at Athens.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Yes my lord,
With every circumstance, the time, the place,
And manner of his death; that it is believed
And told for news with as much confidence
As if 'twere writ in Gallobelgicus.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That's well, that's very well, now Roscio
Follows my part, I must express a grief
Not usual, not like a well left heir
For his dead father, or a lusty widow
For her old husband, must I counterfeit,
But in a deeper, a far deeper strain
Weep like a father for his only son,
Is not that hard to do, ha, Roscio?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O no my lord,
Not for your skill, has not your lordship seen
A player personate Jeronimo?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: By th'mass 'tis true, I have seen the knave paint grief
In such a lively colour, that for false
And acted passion he has drawn true tears
From the spectator's eyes, ladies in the boxes
Kept time with sighs, and tears to his sad accents
As had he truly been the new man he seemed.
Well then I'll ne'er despair; but tell me thou
Thou that hast still been privy to my bosom,
How will this project take?

sp.speaker: Rosc.
sp.l: Rarely my lord,
When now my thinks, I see your lordship's house
Is with suitors of the noblest rank,
And my young lady your supposed heir
Tired more with wooing then the Grecian Queen
In the long absence of her wand'ring lord.
There's not a ruinous nobility
In all this kingdom, but conceives a hope
Now to rebuild his fortunes on this match.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Those are not they I look for, no, my ne●●
Are spread for other game, the rich and greedy
Those that have wealth enough, yet gape for more
They are for me,

sp.speaker: Ros
sp.l: Others will come my lord,
All sorts of fish will press upon your nets,
Then in your lordship's wisdom it must lie
To cull the great ones, and reject the fry.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay fear not that, there's none shall have access
To see my daughter, or to speak to her,
But such as I approve, and aim to catch.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The jest will be, my lord, when you shall see
How your aspiring suitors will put on
The face of greatness, and bely their fortunes
Consume themselves in show, wasting like merchants
Their present wealth in rigging a fair ship
For some ill venture de voyage, that undoes 'em.
Here comes a youth with letters from the court,
Bought of some favourite at such a price
As will for ever sink him, yet alas
All's to no purpose, he must lose the prize.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: This was a jest well thought of, the conceit
Will feed me fat, with sport that it shall make,
Besides the large adventures it brings home
Unto my daughter. How now.Enter servant

sp.speaker: Sir
sp.p: My lord, count Virro is come to see you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Conduct him in; so, so, it takes already
See Roscio see, this is the very man
My project aimed at, the rich count that knows
no end of his large wealth, yet gapes for more
There was no other loadstone could attract
His iron heart, for could beauty have moved him,
Nature has been no niggard to my girl,
But I must to my grief, here comes the count.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Is your lord asleep ?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No sir.
I think not, my lord, count Virro.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: How do you sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I do entreat your lordship pardon, my grief and some want of sleep have made me at this time unmannerly, not fit to entertain guests of your worth.

sp.speaker: Vir
sp.p: Alas sir I know your grief.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: 'Twas that that fetched you hither.Aside.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You've lost a worthy and a hopeful son,
But heaven that always gives, will sometimes take
And that the best, there is no balsam left us
To cure such wounds as these but patience,
There's no disputing with the acts of heaven,
But if there were, in what could you accuse
Those powers that else have been so liberal to you,
And left you yet one comfort in your age:
A fair and virtuous daughter.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Now it begins.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Your blood is not extinct, nor your age childless, from that fair branch that's left may come much fruit to glad posterity, think on that my lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay heaven forbid I should repine at what the
Justice of those powers ordain, it has pleased
Them to confine my care only to one, and to
See her well bestowed is all the comfort I now
Must look for, but if it had pleased heaven that
My son, ah my Eugenio. He weeps.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Alas good gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Fore heaven he does it rarely.

sp.speaker: Vir,
sp.l: But sir, remember yourself, remember your
Daughter, let not your grief for the dead make
you forget the living, whose hopes, and fortunes
Depend upon your safety.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O my good lord, you never had a soon.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Unless they were bastards, and for them no
Doubt but he has done as other lords do.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And therefore cannot tell what 'tis to lose
A son, a good son, and an only son.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I would, my lord, I could as well redress
As I can take compassion of your grief
You should soon find an ease.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Pray pardon me my lord, if I forget myself towards you at this time, if it please you visit my house ofter you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: You would fain sleep my lord, I'll take my leave heaven send you comfort, I shall make bold shortly to visit you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You shall be wondrous welcome,
Wait on my lord out there.Exit Virro.
So now he's gone, how thinkst thou Roscio,
Will not this gudgeon bite?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: No doubt my lord,
So fair a bait would catch a cunning fish.

sp.speaker: Po●..
sp.l: And such a one is he, he ever loved
The beauty of my girl, but that's not it
Can draw the earth bred thoughts of his gross soul
Gold is the god of his idolatry,
With hope of which I'll feed him, till at length
I make him fasten, and Ixion like
For his loved Juno grasp an empty cloud.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: How stands my young lady affected to him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: There's all the difficulty, we must win her to love 〈◊〉, I doubt the peevish girl will think him too 〈◊〉, he's well near threescore: in this business I must leave somewhat to thy wit and care, praise him beyond all measure.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Your lordship ever found me trusty.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If thou effect it, I will make thee happy.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Eugenio's sister then is the rich heir
By his decease.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Yes, and the fair one too,
She needs no gloss that fortune can set on her,
Her beauty of itself were prize enough
To make a King turn beggar for.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hoy day,
What in love Clerimont, I lay my life 'tis so,
Thou couldst not praise her with such passion else.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I know not, but I slept well enough last night,
But if thou sawest her once, I would not give
A farthing for thy life, I tell thee Philocles'
One fight of her would make thee cry, ay me,
Sigh, and look pale, methinks I do imagine
How like an idolatrous lover thou wouldst look
Through the eyelids, know nobody .

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, but how did your worship scape
You have seen her.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: True, but I have an
Antidote, and I can teach it thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: When
I have need on't I'll desire it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And 'twill
Be worth thy learning, when thou shalt see the
Tyranny of that same scurvy boy, and what fools
He makes of us; shall I describe the beast?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What beast?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: A lover.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Then to be brief, I will pass over the opinion of your ancient fathers, as likewise those strange loves spoken of in the authentic histories of chivalry Amadis du Gaul, Parismus, the knight of the sun, or the witty knight don Quixot de la Manca, where those brave men, neither enchantments, giants, windmills, nor flocks of sheep could vanquish, are made the trophies of triumphing love.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Prithee come to the matter.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
Neither will I mention the complaints of sir Guy for the fair Phelis, nor the travels of Parismus for the love of the beauteous Laurana, nor lastly, the most sad penance of the ingenious knight don Quixot upon the mountains of Sierra Morenna, moved by the unjust disdain of the lady Dulcinea del Toboso, 〈◊〉 or our modern authors, I
will not so much as name them, no not that excellent treatise of Tully's love, written by the master of art.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I would thou wouldst pass over this passing over of authors, and speak thine own judgement.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why then to be brief, I think a lover looks like an ass.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I can describe him better than so myself, he looks like a man that had sitten up at cards all night, or a stale drunkard wakened in the midst of his sleep.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: But Philocles, I would not have thee see this lady, she has a bewitching look.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How darest thou venture man, what strange medicine hast thou found, Ovid near taught it thee, I doubt I guess thy remedy, for love, go to a bawdy house or so, is't not?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Faith, and that's a good way I can tell you, we younger brothers are beholding to it, alas we must not fall in love and choose whom we like best, we have no jointures for 'em, as you blessed heirs can have.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well I have found you sir, and prithee tell me, how gottest thou wenches?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Why I can want no panders, I lie in the constable's house.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And there you may whore by authority,
But Clerimont, I doubt this paragon
That thou so praisest, is some ill favoured wench
Whom thou wouldst have me laugh at for commending.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: By heaven I spoke in earnest, trust your eyes,
I'll show you her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How canst thou do it?
Thou knowest this lady's father is to mine
A deadly enemy, nor is his house,
Open to any of our kindred.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: That's no matter,
My lodging's the next door to this lords house,
And my back window looks into his garden,
There every morning fair Leucothoe,
(For so I hear her named) walking alone,
To please her senses makes Aurora blush,
To see on brighter than her soft appear.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Well I will see her there ▪Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Yet for her sake be advised better sir,

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Impudent rascal, canst look me i'th face,
And know how thou hast wronged me, thou hast
Dishonoured my daughter, made a whore on her.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Gentle sir,
The wrong my love has made to your fair daughter
'Tis now too late to wish undone again,
But if you please, it may be yet closed up
Without dishonour, I will marry her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Marry her, she has a hot catch of that, marry a beggar, what jointure canst thou make her?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Sir I am poor I must confess,
Fortune has blessed you better, but I swear
By all things that can bind, 'twas not your wealth
Was the foundation of my true built love,
It was her single uncompounded self,
Herself without addition that I loved,
Which shall for ever in my sight outweigh
All other women's fortunes, and themselves,
And were I great, as great as I could wish
Myself for her advancement, no such bar
As fortune's inequality should stand
Betwixt our loves.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Good father hear me.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Dost thou not blush to call me father, strumpet I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: But hear me
Sir, my shame will be your own.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: No more I say, Francisco leave my house, I charge you come not here.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: I must obey and will,
Dear Luce be constant.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Till death

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Here's a fine wedding towards, the
Bridegroom when he comes for his bride,
shall find her great with child by another man,
Passion a me minion, how have you hid it so long?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fearing your anger sit, I strived to hide it.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Hide it one day more then, or be damned,
Hide it till shallow be married to thee,
And then let him do his worst.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Sir I should too much wrong him.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Wrong him, there be great ladies have done the like, 'tis no news to see a bride with child.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Then be wise, lay the child to him, he's a rich man, tother's a beggar.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I dare not sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Do it I say, and he shall father it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: He knows he never touch me sir.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That's all one, lay it to him, we'll out face him 'tis his: but hark, he is coming, I hear the music, swear thou wilt do thy best to make him think 'tis his, swear quickly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Go step aside, and come when thy que is, thou shalt hear us talk. Luce aside.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Morrow father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Son bridegroom welcome, you have been looked for here.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: My tailor a little disappointed me, but is my bride ready.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes long ago, but you and I will talk a little, send in your music.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Go wait within, and tell me father, did she not
Think it long till I came.

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.l: I warrant
Her she did, she loves ▪ you not a little.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay that I dare swear, she has given me many
Tastes of her affection.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: What before you
Were married.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I mean, in the way
Of honesty father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay that I doubt,
Young wits love to be trying, and to say
Truth, I see not how a woman can deny a man
Of your youth and person upon those terms,
you'll not be known on't now.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I have kissed
Her or so.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come, come, I know you are no
Fool, I should think you a very ass, nay I tell
You plainly, I should be loath to marry my
Daughter to you if I thought you had not tried
Her in so long acquaintance, but you have tried
Her, and she poor soul could not deny you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Ha ha hae.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Faith tell me son, 'tis but a
Merry question, she's yours.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Upon my
Virginity father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Swear not by that,
I'll ne'er believe you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Why then as I am
A gentleman I never did it that I remember.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: That you remember, o is't thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He'll take it upon him presently.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: You have been so familiar with her,
You have forgotten the times, but did you never
Come in half fuddled, and then in a kind humour,
Caetera quis nescit.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Indeed I was wont to serve my mother's maids so when I came half foxed as you said, and then next morning I should laugh to myself.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Why there it goes, I thought to have chid you son shallow, I knew what you had done, 'tis too apparent, I would not have people take notice of it pray God she hide her great belly as she goes to church today.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Why father is she with child?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: As if you knew not that, fie, fie, leave your dissembling now.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: Sure it cannot be mine.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: How's this, you would not make my daughter a whore, would you? this is but to try if you can stir my choler, your wits have strange tricks, do things over night when you are merry, and then deny 'em. But stay, here she comes alone, step aside, she shall not see us,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Ah my dear shallow, thou needst not have made
Such haste, my heart thou knowest was firm enough
To thee, but I may blame my own fond love,
that could not deny thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: She's with child indeed, it swells,

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You would not believe me, 'tis a good wench,
She does it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But yet I know if
Thou hadst been thyself, thou wouldst near have
Offered it, 'twas drink that made thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Yes sure, I was drunk when I did it, for I had
Forgotten it ▪ I lay my life 'twill prove a girl
Because 'twas got in drink.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am ashamed to see anybody .

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Alas poor wretch, go comfort her, Luce.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sweet heart, nay never be ashamed, I was a little too hasty, but I'll make thee amends, we'll be married presently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Be cheery Luce, you were man and wife before, it wanted but the ceremony of the church, and that shall be presently done.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I ay, sweet heart, as soon as may be.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: But now I think on't son shallow, your wedding must not now be public, as we intended it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Because I would not have people take notice of this fault, we'll go to church, only we three, the minister and the clerk, that's witnesses enough, so the time being unknown, people will think you were married before.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: But will it stand with my worship to be married in private.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the greatest do it, when they have been 〈◊〉 before hand, there is no other way to save your bride's credit.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come let's about it presently.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: This is closed up beyond our wishes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am undone, unless, thy wit Francisco,
Can find some means to free me from this fool,
Who would have thought the sot could be so gross
To take upon him what he never did,
to his own shame, I'll send to my Francisco,
And I must lose no time, for I am dead,
If not delivered from this loathed bed.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter Philocles, Clerimont at the window.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: See Philocles, yonder's that happy shade,
That often veils the fair Lucothoe,
And this her usual hour, she'll not be long,
Than thou shalt tell me, if so rare an object
Ere blessed thine eyes before.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well, I would see her once,
Wert but to try thy judgement Cleremont.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: And when thou dost, remember what I told thee,
I would not be so sick, but soft look to thy heart,
Yonder she comes, and that's her waiting woman.
sp.stage: Leucothoe and Psecas in the garden.
sp.l: Now gaze thy fill, speak man how likest thou her.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Psecas.

sp.speaker: Psecas.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: What flower was that
That thou wert telling such a story of
Last night to me.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: 'Tis call Narcissus madam ▪
It bears the name of that too beauteous boy,
That lost himself by loving of himself,
Who viewing in affair and crystal stream
Those lips that only he could never kiss,
Dotes on the shadow, which to reach in vain
Striving, he drownes thus scorning all beside
For the loved shadow the fairer substance died.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Fie fie, I like not these impossible tales,
A man to fall in love with his own shadow,
And died for love, it is most ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Madam I know not, I have often seen
both men and women court the looking glass
With so much seeming contentation,
That I could think this true, nay wear it about 'em
As lovers do their mistress counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: That's not for love, but to correct their beauties
And draw from others admiration,
For all the comfort that our faces give
Unto ourselves is but reflection
Of that fair liking that another takes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I would we were a little nearer 'em
We might but hear what talk these wenches have
When they are alone, I warrant some good stuff.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis happiness enough for me to see
The motion of her lips.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: I'faith is't thereabouts .
Why Philocles, what lost already man,
Struck dead with one poor glance, look up for shame
And tell me how thou likest my judgement now,
Now thou dost see.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ah Cleremont too well,
Too well I see what I shall never taste,
You lady's beauty: she must needs be cruel
(Though her fair shape deny it) to the son
Of him that is her father's enemy,
That, Cleremont, that fatal difference
Cheques my desire, and sinks my rising hopes,
But love's a torrent violent if stopped,
And I am desperately mad: I must
I must be hers, or else I must not be.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.l: Contain that passion that will else overwhelm
All virtue in you, all that is called man,
And should be yours, take my advice my heart
My life to second you, let us consult,
You may find time to speak to her and woe her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: May, nay I will in spite of destiny,
Let women and faint hearted fools complain
In languishing despair, a manly love
dares show itself and press to his desires
Through thickest troops of horrid opposites,
Were there a thousand waking dragons set
To keep that golden fruit: I would attempt
To pluck and taste it, 'tis the danger crowns
A brave achievement: what if I should go
And boldly woo her in her father's house
In spite enmity, what could they say?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: 'Twere madness that not wisdom rash attempts
Betray the means, but never work the end.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She would not hate a man for loving her,
Or if she did, better be once deemed
Then live for ever hapless.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But take time,
The second thoughts our wise men say are best.

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.l: Delay's a double death, no I have thought
A means, that straight I'll put in execution,
I'll write a letter to her presently,
Take how it will.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A letter, who shall carry it?

sp.speaker: Pli.
sp.p: I'll tell thee when I have done, hast thou pen and ink in thy chamber.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, there is one upon the table, I'll stay here at the window, and watch whether she stay or not, what a sudden change is this.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Did not count Virro promise to be hear
Today at dinner.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Yes madam that he did, and I dare swear
He will not break.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: He needs not, he is rich enough, unless
He should break in knavery, as some of our merchants do now adays.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Break promise madam I mean, and that he will not
For your sake, you know his business.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I would I did not, he might spare his pains
And that unusual cost, that he bestows
In pranking up himself, and please me better
he would not please his tailor and his barber,
For they got more for your sake by their lord
Then they got this twenty years before.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ah Psecas, Psecas, can my father think
That I can love count Virro, one so old
(That were enough to make a match unfit)
But one so base, a man that never loved
For any thing called good, but dross and pelf,
One that would never, had my brother lived
Have moved this suit, no I can never love him,
But canst thou keep a secret firmly Psecas.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.p: Doubt me not madam.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Well I'll tell thee then,
I love, alas, I dare not say I love him,
But there's a young and noble gentleman,
Lord Euphues son, my father's enemy.
A man whom nature's prodigality
Stretched even to envy in the making up,
Once from a window my pleased eye beheld
This youthful gallant as he road the street,
On a curvetting courser, who it seemed
Knew his fair load, and with a proud disdain
Checked the base earth, my father being by
I asked his name, he told me Philocles,
The son and heir of his great enemy:
Judge Psecas then, how my divided breast,
Suffered between two meeting contraries,
Hatred and love, but loves a deity,
And must prevail against mortals, whose command
Not Jove himself could ever yet withstand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What is the letter done already, I see these lovers have nimble inventions, but how will you send it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What a question's that, seest thou this stone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ah, than I see your drift, this stone must guide your
Fleeting letter in the air, and carry it to that
Fair mark you aim at.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hard by her.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I think you would not hit her with such stones as this,
Lady look to yourself, he that now throws one
Stone at you, hopes to hit you with two.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: But prithee tell me what dost think this letter may do.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Well I hope,
'Tis ten to one this lady oft hath seen you,
You never lived obscure in Syracuse,
Nor walked the streets unknown, and who can tell
What place you bear in her affections,
Loved or misliked; if bad, this letter sent,
Will make her show her scorn, if otherwise,
Fear not a woman's wit, she'll find a time
To answer your kind letter, and express
What you desire she should, then send it boldly,
You have a fairer make there.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Cupid guide my arm,
O be as just blind God as thou art great,
And with that powerful hand, that golden shaft
That I was wounded, wound you tender breast,
There is no salve but that, no cure for me,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See what a wonder it strikes 'em in, how it should come.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: She'll wonder more to see what man it comes from.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I like her well, yet she is not afraid to open it:
She starts, stay mark her action when she has read the letter.

body.l: "Let it wrong this letter that it came,
" from one that trembled to subscribe his name,
"Fearing your hate, oh let not hate descend,
" nor make you cruel to so vowed a friend,
"If you'll not promise love, grant but access,
" and let me know my woes are passed redress,
"Be just then beauteous judge, and like the laws
" condemn me not till you have heard my cause,
"Which when you have, from those fair lips return
" either my life in love, or death in scorn.

sp.l: Am I awake or dream I, is it true
Or does my flattering fancy but suggest
What I most covet.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Madam the words are there,
I'll swear it canna be, nor be illusion.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: It is too good for truth.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mock me not fortune,
She kissed it, sawest thou her, by heaven she kissed it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And with a look that relished love, not scorn,

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: This letter may be forged, I much desire to know the certainty, Psecas thy help must further me.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.p: I'll not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Here comes my father, he must not see this.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.p: No nor your tother sweet heart, he is with him yonder.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Nay noble count you are too old a soldier
To take a maid's first no, for a denial,
They will be nice at first, men must pursue
That will obtain, woe her my lord and take her,
You have my free consent if you can get hers,
Yonder she walks alone, go comfort her.

sp.speaker: Virro
sp.l: I'll do the best I may, but we old men
Are but cold comfort, I thank your lordship's love.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I wonder Roscio that the peevish girl
Comes on so slowly on persuasions
That I can use, do move the setting forth
Count Virro's greatness, wealth and dignity
Seems not to affect her, Roscio.

sp.speaker: Roscio.
sp.l: I doubt the cause my lord,
For were not that, I dare engage my life,
she would be won to love him, she has placed
Already her affections on some other.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: How should I find it out

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why thus my lord
There's never man nor woman that ere loved,
But chose some bosom friend whose close converse,
Sweeten their joys, and ease their burdened minds
Of such a working secret, thus no doubt
Has my young lady done, and but her woman,
Who should it be, 'tis she must out with it,
Her secrecy if wit cannot o'erreach,
Gold shall corrupt, leave that to me my lord,
But if her lady's heart do yet stand free
And unbequeathed to any, your command
And father's jurisdiction interposed
Will make her love the count, no kind of means
Must want to draw her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou art my oracle,
My brain, my soul, my very being Roscio,
Walk on and speed whilst I but second thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: It is even so, count Virro is your rival,
See how the old ape smugs up his mouldy chaps
To seize the bit.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: He must not if I live,
But yet her father brings him that has the means
That I should ever want.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If he do marry her
Revenge it nobly, make him a cuckold boy,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thou jests that feels it not, prithee let's go,

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Stay, I'll not curse him briefly for thy sake,
If thou dost marry her mayest thou be made
A cuckold without profit, and ne'er get
An office by it, nor favour at the court,
But may thy large ill got treasury
Be spent in her bought lust, and thine own gold
Bring thee adulterers, so farewell good count.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: My lord, there's a messenger within
Desire's access, has business of import,
Which to no ear but yours he must impart.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Admit him, now friend, your business with me.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: If you be the lord Polimetes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: My lord, I come from Athens with such news
As I dare say is welcome though unlooked for,
Your son Eugenio lives whom you so long
Thought dead and mourned for.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How, lives.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Upon my life my lord I saw him well
Within these few days.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thanks for thy good news,
Towards him Roscio, but now tell me friend
Hast thou revealed this news to any man
In Syracuse but me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: To none my lord,
At every place where I have stayed in town,
Enquiring for your lordship's house, I heard
These tragic, but false news, the contrary
I still concealed, though knew, intending first
Your lordship's ear should drink it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Worthy friend.
I now must thank your wisdom as your love
In this well carried action, I'll requite it,
Mean time pray use my house, and still continue your
Silence in this business, Roscio make him welcome, and
Part as little from him as you can for fear.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Think it done, my lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Psecas come hither.

sp.speaker: Vi●
sp.l: Be like yourself, let not a cruel doom
Pass those fair lips, that never were ordained
to kill, but to revive.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Neither my lord
Lies in the power to do.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Yes sweet to me.
Whom your scorn kills, and pity will revive.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Pity is showed to men in misery.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And so am I, if not relieved by you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: 'Twere pride in me, my lord, to think it so.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I am your beauties captive.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Then my lord,
What greater gift than freedom can I give,
'Tis that that captives most desires, and that
You shall command, you're free from me my lord,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Your beauty contradicts that freedom lady.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come noble count, I must for this time interrupt you
You'll find time enough within to talk.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I'll wait upon your lordship.Exeunt manet Euge. solus.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: Thus in disguise I have discovered all,
And found the cause of my reported death,
Which did at first amaze me, but 'tis well,
'Tis to draw on the match between my sister
And this rich count, heaven grant it be content
As well as fortune to her, but I fear
She cannot love his age, how it succeeds
I shall perceive, and whilst unknown I stay,
I cannot hurt the project, help I may. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This will make good work for you in the spiritual
Court, shallow is a rich man.

sp.speaker: Summoner
sp.l: I marry sir,
Those are the men we look for, there's somewhat
To be got, the court has many businesses at this
Time, but they are little worth, a few waiting
Women got with child by serving-men or so, scarce
Worth the citing.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Do not their masters get
'Em with child sometimes.

sp.speaker: Summoner
sp.l: Yes no doubt, but
They have got a trick to put 'em off upon their
Men, and for a little portion save their
own credits; besides, these private marriages
Are much out of our way, we cannot know when
There is a fault.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Well, these are no
Starters I warrant you, shallow shall not deny it,
And for the wench she need not confess it, she has
A mark that will betray her.

sp.speaker: Summoner
sp.l: I thank you
Sir for your good intelligence, I hope 'tis certain.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Fear not that, is your citation ready.

sp.speaker: Summoner
sp.p: I have it here.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Well step aside, and come when I call, I hear 'em coming. Exit Sumner.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Set forward there, Francisco what make you here.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: I come to claim my right, parson take heed,
Thou art the author of adultery
If thou conjoin this couple, she's my wife.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: You saucebox.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Father, I thought she had been mine, I hope I shall not lose her thus.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Francisco, dare not to interrupt us, for I swear thou shalt endure the law's extremity
For thy presumption.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Do your worst, I fear not,
I was contracted to her.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: What witness have you.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Heaven is my witness, whose imperial eye saw our contract.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: What an ass is this to talk of contracting, he that will get a wench, must make her bigger as I have done, and not contract.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Sir, you are abused.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Why so.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: The wife you go to marry is with child, and by another.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: A good jest i'faith, make me believe that.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: How comes this fool possessed, he never touched her I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: No more Francisco as you will answer it,
Parson set forward there.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Stay,
If this will not suffice, Sumner come forth.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: A sumner, we are all betrayed. Enter Sumner.

sp.speaker: Summoner
sp.l: God save you all, I think you guess my business,
these are to cite to the spiritual court
You master shallow, and you mistress Luce,
Ask not the cause, for 'tis apparent here,
A carnal copulation, ante matrimonium.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This was a bar unlooked for, spiteful Francisco

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Injurious franklin, could the laws divine,
Or humane suffer, such an impious act,
That thou shouldst take my true and lawful wife,
And great with child by me, to give t'another,
Gulling his poor simplicity.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Do you mean me sir.

sp.speaker: Summoner
sp.p: Gallants farewell, my writ shall be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Summer it shall.Exit summer

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.l: I'll take my leave, there's nothing now for me to do

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Farewell good master parson. Exit parson

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Francisco canst thou say thou ever lovedst my daughter, and wouldst thou thus disgrace her openly.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: No, I would win her thus,
And did you hold her credit half so dear
As I, or her content, you would not thus
Take her from me, and thrust her against her will
On this rich fool.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: You are very bold with me sir.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: Let me have news what happens dearest luce.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Else let me die.Exit Francisco.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This was your doing Luce, it had been
Unpossible he should ere have known the time
So truly else, but I'll take an order next time
For you babbling.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: What's the matter father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: We may
Thank you for it, this was your haste that will
Now shame us all, you must be doing a fore your
Time.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Twas but a trick of youth father,

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: And therefore now you must e'en stand in a
White sheet for all to gaze at.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How,
I would be loath to wear a surplice now, 'tis a
Disgrace the house of the shallows never knew ▪

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: All the hope is, officers may be bribed, and so they will, 'twere a hard world for us to live in else.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: You say true father, if 'twere not for corruption, every poor rascal might have justice as well as one of us, and that were a shame.Exeunt Shal. Luce

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: This was a cunning stratagem well laid,
But yet Francisco thou'st not won the prize:
What should I do, I must not let this cause
Proceed to trial in the open court,
For then my daughter's oath will cast the child
Upon Francisco: no, I have found a better,
I will before the next court day provide
Some needy parson, one whose poverty
Shall make him fear no cannons, he shall marry
My daughter to rich shallow, when 'tis done
Our gold shall make a silence in the court. Exit ▪

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: I must return your answer to my lady,
He tell her you will come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come,
And such a angel call, I should forget
All offices of nature, all that men
Wish in their second thoughts, ere such a duty
Commend my service to her, and to you
My thanks for this kind message.Exit Psecas.
I never breathed till now, never till now now
Did my life relish sweetness, break not heart,
Crack not ye feeble ministers of nature
With inundation of such swelling joy,
Too great to bear without expression:
The lady writes that she has known me long
By sight, and loved me, and she seems to thank
Her stars she loves, and is beloved again,
She speaks my very thoughts, by heaven 'tis strange
And happy when affections thus can meet;
She further writes at such an hour today,
her father's absence, and all household spies
Fitly removed, shall give access to me
Unmarked to visit her, where she alone
Will entertain discourse and welcome me.
I hope 'tis truly meant, why should I fear,
But wisdom bids me fear: fie, fie, 'tis base,
To wrong a creature of that excellence,
With such suspicion I should injure her,
I will as soon suspect an angel false,
Treason ne'er lodged within so fair a breast,
No, if her hand betray me, I will will run
On any danger, 'tis alike to me
To die, or find her false, for on her truth
Hangs my chief being, well I'll lose no time
No not a minute, dearest love I come,
To meet my sweetest wishes I will fly,
Heaven and my truth, shield me from treachery. Exit.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I cannot credit it, nor think that she
Of all the noble youth in Sicily,
Should make so strange a choice, that none but he,
None but the son of my vowed enemy
Must be her mate, it strikes me to amaze,
Minion take heed, do not belie your mistress.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.l: Mercy forsake me if I do my lord,
You charged me to confess the truth to you,
Which I have fully done, and presently
I'll bring you where concealed, you shall both see
Their privacy and hear their conference.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well I believe thee wench, and will reward
Thy trust in this, go get thee in again
And bring me word when Philocles is come,
sir you'll be secret to our purpose.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: As your own breast my lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I shall rest thankful to you:
This stranger must be soothed lest he mar all.

sp.speaker: Rosc.
sp.p: This was well found out my lord, you now have means to take your enemy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: With blessed occasion I will so pursue
As childless Euphes shall for ever rue.
Rise in thy blackest look direst Nemesis
Assistant to my purpose, help me glut
My thirsty soul with blood. This bold young man
To his rash love shall sacrifice his life.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: What course you intend, to ruin him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why kill him presently.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O no my lord,
You'll rue that action, think not that the law
Will let such murder sleep unpunished.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Should I now let him go now I have caught him

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Yes sir, to catch him faster, and more safely.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How should that be? speak man.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why thus my lord;
You know the law speaks death to any man
That steals an heir without her friend's consent,
This must he do, his love will prompt him to it,
For he can never hope by your consent
To marry her, and she 'tis like will give
Content, for women's love is violent,
Then mark their passage you shall easily find
How to surprise them at your will my lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou art my oracle dear Roscio,
Here's Psecas come again; how now what news?

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.p: My lord they both are coming please you withdraw, you shall both hear and see what you desire.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ye are welcome noble sir and did my power,
Answer my love your visitation,
should be more free, and your deserved welcome
Expressed in better fashion.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Best of ladies,
It is so well, so excellently well,
Coming from your wished love, my barren thanks
Wants language for't, there lies in your fair looks
More entertainment than in all the pomp
That the vain Persian ever taught the world,
Your presence is the welcome I expected,
That makes it perfect.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: 'Tis your noble thought
Makes good what's wanting here, but gentle friend,
For so I now dare call you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: 'Tis well minion you are bold
Enough I see to choose your friends without my leave.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: 'Tis my ambition ever to be yours.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Think me not light, dear Philocles, so soon
To grant thee love, that others might have sought
With eagerest pursuit, and not obtained,
But I was yours by fate, and long have been,
Before you wood Leucothoe was won,
And yours without resistance.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O my stars
'Twas your kind influence, that whist I slept
In dullest ignorance, contrived for me
The way to crown me with felicity.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You may be deceived though,
You have no such great reason
To thank your stars if you knew all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And know fair mistress you have met a love,
That time, nor fate, nor death can ever change,
A man that but in you can have no being:
Let this kiss seal my faith.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: And this mine.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay to't again, your sweet meat shall have sour sauce.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: But sweet, 'mongst all these roses there's one thorn
That pricks and galls me, our parents enmity
Will cross our loves, I do assure my son
This father never will give his consent.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No so I think, he moves me still to Virro
That old crazed count, and with such vehemency
I dare scarce bide his presence if I deny him;
Therefore we must be speedy in our course,
And take without his leave what he denies.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I thank you for that good daughter.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I told you sir 'twould come to this at last.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O thou hast spoke my wishes, and hath showed
Thyself in love as true as beautiful;
Then let's away dearest Leucothoe,
My fortunes are not poor, then fear no want,
This constant love of ours may prove so happy,
To reconcile our parents enmity.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Heaven grant it may.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Never by this means youngster.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: But soft now I think better on't I'll not go.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Why dearest, is thy love so quickly cold?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: No, but I'll not venture thee, thine is the danger,
Thou knowest 'tis death by law to steal an heir,
And my dear brothers most untimely death,
Hath lately made me one, what if thou shouldst be taken.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O fear not that, had I a thousand lives,
They were too small a venture for such prize,
I tell thee sweet, a face not half so fair
As thine, hath armed whole actions in the field,
And brought a thousand ships to Tenedos,
To sack lamented Troy, and should I fear
To venture one poor life, and such a life
As would be lost in nor possessing thee:
Come come, make that no scruple, when shall we go.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: This present evening, for tomorrow morning
My father looks that I should give consent
To marry with the count,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Best of all, would 'twere this present hour,
I'll go prepare, but shall I call thee here.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: O no, we'll meet.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Where dearest.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: East from the city by a river's side,
not distant half a mile there stands a grove,
Where often riding by I have observed
A little hermitage, there I will stay
If I be first, if you, do you the like,
Let th'hour be ten, then shall I best escape.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ne'er sweeter comfort came from angels lips
I know the place, and will be ready there
Before the hour: I'll bring a friend with me
As true as mine own heart, one Clerimont,
That may do us good if danger happen.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Use your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Dearest farewell,
Hours will seem years till we are met again.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Ah sirrah, this gear goes well, god a mercy girl
For thy intelligence, why this is as much as a
Man could desire, the time, place, and every thing;
I warrant 'em they pass no further, well
Go thou in and wait upon thy mistress, she's
Melancholy till she see her sweet heart again, but
When she does, she shall not see him long,
Not a word of what's passed among us for your life.

sp.speaker: Pse.
sp.p: I warrant you my lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I'll not so much as show an angry look,
Or any token that I know any of their proceedings,
But Rosio, we must lay the place strongly, if they
Should scape us, I were prettily fooled now after all
This.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Why 'tis impossible my lord, we'll go
Strong enough, besides I think it fit we took
An officer along with us to countenance it the
Better.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou sayest well, go get one,
I'll go myself along with you too, I love
To see sport though I am old, you'll go
Along with us to sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I sir, you shall
Command my service when you are ready.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now Euphues, what I did but barely act
Thy bleeding heart shall feel, loss of a son
If law can have his course, as who can let it,
I know thou think'st mine dead, and in thy heart
laughest at my falling house, but let them laugh
That win the prize, things ne'er are known till ended.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Well I like my sister's choice, she has taken a man
Whose very looks and carriage speak him
Worthy, besides he is noble, his fortunes sufficient,
They both love each other, what can my father
More desire, that he gapes so after this old
Count ▪ that comes for the estate, as tother upon
My soul does not, but pure spotless love, but
Now his plot is for revenge upon his old enemy:
Fie, fie 'tis bloody and unchristian, my soul
Abhors such acts, this match may rather
Reconcile our houses, and I desire where worth
Is to have friendship, as on my soul 'tis there.
Well Philocles I hope to call thee brother.
Somewhat I'll do, I'll go persuade count Virro
Not to love her, I know the way, and I'll but
Tell him truth her brother lives, that will
Cool his love quickly; but soft, here comes
The count as fit as may be.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: She loves me not yet, but that's no matter,
I shall have her, her father says I shall,
And I dare take his word, maids are quickly
Overruled, ah, ah, methinks I am grown younger
Than I was by twenty years, this fortune
Cast upon me, is better than Medea's charm, to
Make an old man young again, to have a
Lord's estate freely bestowed, and with it such
A beauty as should warm Nestor's blood,
Make old Priam lusty. Fortune I see thou lovest me
Now, I'll build a temple to thee shortly, and
adore thee as the greatest deity. Now what are you.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.l: A poor scholar my lord, one that
Am little beholding to fortune.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: So are most of your profession,
Thou shouldst take some more thriving
Occupation, to be a judge's man, they are
The bravest now adays, or a Cardinal's
Pander, that were a good profession and gainful.

sp.speaker: Euge.
sp.p: But not lawful, my lord.

sp.speaker: Verro.
sp.l: Lawful,
That Cardinal may come to be Pope, and
Then he could pardon thee and himself too.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My lord I was brought up a scholar.
And I thank your counsel, my
Lord, I have some for you, and therefore I
Came.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: For me, what I prithee.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: 'Tis weighty and concerns you near.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Speak, what is't?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: My lord, you are to marry old Polimetes daughter.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: And heir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: No heir
My lord, her brother is alive.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: How, thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My lord,
What I speak is true, and to my knowledge
His father gives it out in policy to marry his
Daughter the better, to hook in suitors, and
Specially aimed at you, thinking you rich
And covetous, and now he has caught you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: But dost thou mock me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Let me be ever miserable if I speak
Not truth, as sure as I am here Eugenio lives,
I know it, and know him, where he is.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Where prithee.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Not a day's journey hence,
Where his father enjoined him to stay till your
Match, and sends word to him of this plot:
Besides, I overheard the old lord and his man
Roscio, laughing at you for being caught thus.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why, wert thou at the house then.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Yes, but had scurvy entertainment
Which I have thus revenged

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Beshrew my heart I know not what
To think on't, till like enough, this lord was
Always cunning beyond measure, and it
Amazed me that he should grow so extreme
Kind to me on the sudden to offer me all this:
Besides this fellow is so confident, and on
No ends of cozenage that I can see; well,
I would fain enjoy her, the wench is
Delicate, but I would have the estate too, and
Not be gulled, what shall I do, now brains
If ever you will, help your master.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It stings him.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Well, so, sir,
What may I call your name?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Irus my lord.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Your name as well as your attire
Speakers you poor.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I am so.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: And very poor.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Very poor.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Would you not gladly take a course
To get money, and a great some of money.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Is gladly if your lordship would but
Show me the way.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Hark ye.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: O my lord, conscience.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Fie, never
Talk of the conscience, and for law thou art
Free, for all men think him dead, and
His father will be ashamed to follow it
Having already given him for dead,
And then who can know it, come be wise,
Five hundreth crowns I'll give.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Well, 'tis poverty that does it, and not I,
When shall I be paid.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: When thou hast done it.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Well give me your
Hand for it my lord

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: In writing, to be paid when I have
Poisoned him, and think it done.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Now thou
But love has made me bold, the time has been,
In such a place as this I should have feared
Each rolling leaf, and trembled at a reed
Stirred in the moonshine, my fearful fancy
Would frame a thousand apparitions,
And work some fear out of my very shadow:
I wonder Philocles is tardy thus,
When last we parted every hour, he said,
Would seem a year till we were met again,
It should not seem so by the haste he makes
I'll sit and rest me, come I know he will.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This Clerimont this is the happy place
Where I shall meet the sum of all my joys,
And be possessed of such a treasury
As would enrich a monarch.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: This is his voice,
My Philocles.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My life, my soul, what here before me,
O thou dost still out go me, and dost make
All my endeavours poor in the requital
Of thy large favours, but I forget myself.
Sweet bid my friend here welcome, this is he
That I dare trust next mine own hearth with secrets.
But why art thou disguised thus.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I durst not venture else to make escape.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Even now methinks I stand as I would wish
With all my wealth about me, such a love
And such a friend, what can be added more
To make a man live happy, thou dark grove
That hast been called the seat of melancholy,
and shelter for the discontented spirits;
Sure thou art wrong, thou seemst to me a place
Of solace and content, a paradise
That givest me more than ever court could do
Or richest palace, blessed be thy fair shades,
Let birds of music ever chant it here,
No croaking raven, or ill boding owl
Make here their baleful habitation
Frighting thy walks, but mayst thou be a grove
Where loves fair Queen may take delight to sport:
For under thee two faithful lovers meet,
Why is my fair Leucothoe so sad.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: I know no cause, but I would fain be gone.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Whether sweet.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Any whether from hence.
My thoughts divine of treason, whence I know not,
There is no creature knows our meeting here
But one, and that's my maid, she has been trusty
And will be still I hope, but yet I would
She did not know it, prithee let's away
Anywhere else, we are secure from danger.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then let's remove, but prithee be not sad.
What noise is that.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O fear not love.Draw.

div.stage: Enter Polimedes', Roscio, Eugenio and officers.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Upon 'em officers, yonder they are.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Thieves, villains.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thou art the thief and the villain too,
Give me my daughter thou ravisher.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: First take my life.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Upon 'em I say.Fight.
Knock 'em down officers if they resist,They are taken.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: O they are lost, ah wicked, wicked Psecas;

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
So keep 'em fast, we'll have 'em faster shortly, and for you minion, I'll tie a clog about your neck for running
away any more.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Yet do but hear me father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Call me not father thou disobedient wretch,
Thou runaway, thou art no child of mine,
My daughter ne'er wore breeches.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: O sir, my mother would have done as much
For love of you, if need had so required,
Think not my mind transformed as my habit.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Officers away with 'em, peace strumpet,
You may discharge him, he's but an assistant.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: O stay and hear me yet, hear but a word
And that my last it may be, do not spill
The life of him in whom my life subsists,
Kill not two lives in one, remember sir,
I was your daughter once, once you did love me,
And tell me then, what fault can be so great,
To make a father murderer of his child,
For so you are in taking of his life.
O think not sir that I will stay behind him
Whilst there be asps, and knives, and burning coals ▪
No Roman dame shall in her great example
Outgo my love.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O where will sorrow stay,
Is there no end in grief or in my death
Not punishment enough for my offence,
But must her grief be added to afflict me;
Dry up those pearls dearest Leucothoe,
Or thou wilt make me doubly miserable,
Preserve that life, that I may after death
Live in my better part, take comfort dear,
People would curse me, if such beauty should
For me miscarry, no, live happy thou,
And let me suffer what the law inflicts.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: My offence was as great as thine,
And why should not my punishment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Come have you done, officers away with him.
I'll be your keeper, but I'll look better to you.
But rosy you and I must about the business:
Sir let it be your charge to watch my daughter,
And see she send no message any whither,
Nor receive any.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It shall my lord.Exeunt manet Eu. and Leu.
I'll be an Argus, none shall come here I warrant you,
My very heart bleeds to see two such lovers so
Faithfully parted so. I must condemn my father,
He's too cruel in this hard action, and did not
Nature forbid it, I could rail at him, to reek
His long fostered malice against lord Euphues thus
Upon his son, the faithful lover of his own
Daughter, and upon her, for should it come to pass
As he expects it shall, I think to would kill her
Too, she takes it —: see in what strange amazement
Now she stands, her grief has spent itself so
Far that it has left her senseless, it grieves
Me thus to see her, I can scarce forbear revealing
Of myself to her, but that I keep it for a
Better occasion when things shall better answer to
My purpose: lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: What are you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: In that my lord your father has appointed
To give attendance on you.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: On me, alas I need no attendance,
He might bestow his care better for me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I came but lately to him, nor do I mean
Long to stay with him, in the mean time lady
Might I but do you any service.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: All service is too late, my hopes are desperate.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Madam, I have a feeling of your woe,
A greater your own brother could not have,
And think not that I come suborned by any
To undermine your secrets, I am true,
By all the gods I am, for further trial
Command me any thing, send me on any message
I'll do it faithfully, or any thing else
That my poor power can compass.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: O strange fate
Have I lost pity in a father's heart,
And shall I find it in a stranger: sir
I shall not live to thank you, but my prayers
Shall go with you.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: 'Tis not for thanks or need
But for the service that I owe to virtue
I would do this.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Surely this man
Is nobly bred, howe'er his habit give him:
But sir, all physic comes to me too late,
There is no hope my Philocles should live ▪

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Unless the King were pleased to grant his pardon,
'Twere good that he were moved.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Ah who should do it,
I fear me 'tis in vain, count Virro
And my father both will cross it, but I would venture
If I could get but thither.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: That's in my power
To give you liberty, your father left me
To be your keeper, but in an act
So meritorious as this, I will not hinder you,
Nay I will wait upon you to the court.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: A thousand thanks to you, well I'll go,
Grant o you powers above, if virgin's tears,
If a true love's prayers had ever power
To move compassion grant it now to me,
Armed with so strong a vigour, my weak words
They may pierce deep into his kingly breast,
And force out mercy in spite of all opposers.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Come let's away.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My dearest luce, were thy old sire as just
As thou art truly constant, our firm love
Had never met these oppositions,
All my designs as yet, all practises
That I have used, I see are frustrated,
For as my fair intelligencer writes,
He will before the next court day provide
Some careless person ▪ that in spite of laws
Shall marry her to shallow, this being done,
He means to hold the court's severity
To by a golden bit, and so he may,
Alas it is too true, I must prevent it,
And that in time, before it grow too far;
But how, there lies the point of difficulty:
But what strange sight is this that greets mine eyes,
Alphonso my old captain, sure 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thus once again from twenty years exile,
Tossed by the storms of fortune to and fro,
Has gracious heaven given me leave to tread
My native earth of Sicily and draw
That air that fed me in my infancy.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: 'Tis he, most noble captain, o what power
Has been so gracious as to bless mine eyes
Once more with sight of my most honoured master.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Kind youth the tears of joy that I have spent
To greet my native country have quite robbed
Mine eyes of moisture, and have left me none
To answer thy affection, but tell me,
Tell me how thou hast lived in Syracuse
These five years here, since that unluckily storm
Divided us at sea.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Faith poorly sir,
as one that knows no kindred nor alliance,
Unknown of any have I shifted out,
But I have heard you say that I was born
In Syracuse, tell me what stock I come of,
What parentage, how mean soe'er they be,
They cannot well be poorer than myself,
Speak, do you know them sir?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes very well,
And I am glad the fates have brought me home,
For thy dear sake, that I may now disclose
Thy honourable birth.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: Honourable?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Yes noble youth, thou art the second son
To old lord Euphues, a man more worthy
And truly noble never drew this air;
Thy name's Lysandro, this discovery
Will be as welcome to your friends as you.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: You do amaze me sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I'll tell you all,
It was my fortune, twenty a year ago,
Upon the Tyrrhene shore, whose sea divides
This I'll from Italy, to keep a fort
Under your noble father, where yourself
Then but a child, was left to my tuition,
When suddenly the rude assailing force
Of strong Italian pirates so prevailed,
As to surprisal of the fort and us.
Your name and noble birth I then concealed,
Fearing some outrage from the enmity
Of those fell pirates, and since from yourself
I purposely have kept the knowledge of it.
As loath to grieve your present misery
With knowledge of what fortunes you had lost,
That this is true, you straight shall see th'effect,
I'll go acquaint your father with the tokens,
And make his overjoyed heart leap to embrace
Thee his new found and long forgotten son:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Worthy captain, your presence was always
Welcome to me, but this unlooked for news, I
Cannot suddenly digest.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well I'll go to him presently.Exit Alphonso.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Now my dear luce, I shall find means to quite
Thy love, that couldst descend so low as I
When I was nothing, and with such affection,
This was my suit still to the powers above,
To make me worthy of thy constant love.
Exit Francisco.but I'll about the project I intended.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why now my lord you are nearer to her love then ever you were yet, your rival by this accident shall be removed out of the way, for before the scornful girl would never fancy any man else.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I conceive you sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I laboured it for your sake as much as for my
Own, to remove your rival and my enemy, you
Have your love, and I have my revenge.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I shall live my lord to give you thanks, butAside.
'Twill be after a strange manner, if Irus has
Dispatched what he was hired too, than my kind
Lord I shall be a little too cunning for you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My lord you are gracious with the King.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I thank his majesty, I have his care before another man.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then see no pardon be granted, you may stop any thing; I knew Euphues will be soliciting for his son.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I warrant you my lord no pardon passes whilst I am there, I'll be a bar betwixt him and the King, but hark the King approaches.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Health to your majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Count Virro, and lord Polimetes welcome,
You have been strangers at the court of late;
But I can well excuse you count, you are about a wife,
A young one and a fair one too they say,
get me young soldiers count, but speak
When is the day, I mean to be your guest,
You shall not steal a marriage.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: I thank your majesty, but the marriage that I intended is stolen to my hand, and by another.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Stolen, how man.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My promised wife
Is lately stolen away by Philocles,
Lord Euphues son against her father's will,
Who followed 'em and apprehended them,
The law may right us sir, if it may have course.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No reason but the law should have his course.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.p: Pardon dread sovereign, pardon for my son.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Your son, lord Euphues, what is his offence.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: No heinous one my liege, no plot of treason
Against your royal person or your state,
These aged cheeks would blush to beg a pardon
For such a foul offence, no crying murder
Hath stained his innocent hands, his fault was love,
Love my dear liege, unfortunately he took
The daughter and heir of lord Polimetes,
Who follows him and seeks extremity.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I seek but law, I am abused my liege,
Justice is all I beg, my daughters stolen,
Staff of my age, let the law do me right,

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To his just prayers do I bend my knee
My promised wife is stolen, and by the son
Of that injurious lord, justice I crave.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Be like those powers above, whose place on earth
You represent, show mercy gracious King,
For they are merciful.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Mercy is but the King's prerogative,
'Tis justice is his office, doing that
He can wrong no man, no man can complain,
But mercy showed oft takes way relief
From the wronged party that the law would give him:

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: The law is blind and speaks in general terms,
she cannot pity where occasion serves,
The living law can moderate her rigour,
And that's the King.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The King I hope in this will not do so,

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: 'Tis malice makes thee speak,
Hard hearted lord, hadst thou no other way
To wreak thy cankered and long fostered hate
Upon my head but thus, thus bloodily
By my son's suffering, and for such a fault
As thou shouldst love him rather, is thy daughter
Disparaged by his love, is his blood base,
Or are his fortunes sunk, this law was made
For such like cautions, to restrain the base
From wronging noble persons by attempts
Of such a kind, but where equality
Meets in the match, the fault is pardonable.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: Mercy my sovereign, mercy gracious King.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Minion who sent for you, 'twere more modesty
For you to be at home.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let her alone, speak lady,
I charge you no man interupt her. Enter Leucothoe

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: If ever pity touched that princely breast,
If ever virgins tears had power to move,
Or if you ever loved and felt the pangs
That other lovers do, pity great King,
Pity and pardon two unhappy lovers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Your life is not in question.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Yes royal sir
If law condemn my Philocles, he and I
Have but one heart, and can have but one fate.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Excellent virtue thou hadst not this from thy father.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There's music in her voice, and in her face
More than a mortal beauty ▪ o my heart,
I shall be lost in passion if I hear her,
I'll here no more, convey her from my presence,
Quickly I say.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I told you what he would do, I knew
He would not here of a pardon, and I against it,
He respects me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No doubt he does my lord ▪
I like this passage well.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But stay,
Stay lady, let me hear you, beshrew my heart
My mind was running of another matter.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Where the devil hath his mind been all this while,
Perhaps he heard none of us neither,
We may e'en tell our tales again.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No sure he heard us, but 'tis very strange.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: 'Tis such a tempting poison I draw in,
I cannot stay my draught, rise up lady.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: Never until your grace's pardon raise me,
There's pity in your eye, o show it sir,
Say pardon gracious King, 'tis but a word
And short, but welcome as the breath of life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'll further here the manner of this fact,
Avoid the presence all, all but the lady,
And come not till I send.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I like not this.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Nor I hear is mad dancing.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Heaven bless thy suit thou mirror of thy sex,
And best example of true constant love,
That in the sea of thy transcendent virtues
Drownest all thy father's malice, and redeemest
More in my thoughts then all thy kin can lose.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Now lady what would you do to save the life
Of him you love so dear.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I cannot think that thought I would not do,
Lay it in my power, and beyond my power
I would attempt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You would be thankful then
To me if I should grant his pardon.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: If ever I were thankful to the gods
For all that I call mine, my health and being,
could I to you be unthankful for a gift
I value more than those, without which
These blessings were but wearisome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Those that are thankful study to requite
A courtesy, would you do so? would you requite
This favour ▪

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I cannot sir,
For all the service I can do your grace
Is but my duty, you are my sovereign,
And all my deeds to you are debts not merits,
But to those powers above that can requite,
That from their vastless treasures hope rewards,
More out of grace then merit on us mortals,
To those I'll ever pray that they would give you
More blessings than I have skill to ask.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Nay but Leucothoe, this lies in thy power to requite, thy love will make requital, wilt thou love me?

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I ever did my lord.
I was instructed from my infancy,
To love and honour you my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But in a nearer bond of love.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: There is no nearer nor no truer love
Than that a loyal subject bears a prince.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Still thou wilt not conceive me ▪ I must deal plain
With you, wilt thou lie with me, and I will seal his
Pardon presently; nay more, I'll heap upon you
Both all favours, all honours that a prince can give.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: O me unhappy, in what a sad dilemma stands my choice.
Either to lose the man my soul most loves,
Or save him by a deed of such dishonour
As he will ever loathe me for, and hate
To draw that breath that was so basely kept.
Name any thing but that to save his life,
I know you do but tempt my frailty sir,
I know your royal thoughts could never stoop
To such a soul dishonourable act.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bethink yourself, there is no way but that,
I swear by heaven never to pardon him
But upon those conditions.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: O I am miserable.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art not if not wilful, yield Leucothoe,
It shall be secret, Philocles for his life
Shall thank thy love, but never know the price
Thou paidst for it; be wise thou heardst me swear,
I cannot now show mercy, thou mayst save him,
And if he die, 'tis thou that art the tyrant.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.l: I should be so if I should save him thus,
Nay I should be a traitor to your grace,
Betray your soul to such a foe as lust,
But since your oath is past, dear Philocles
I'll show to thee an honest cruelty,
And rather follow thee in spotless death,
Then buy with sinning a dishonoured life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet pity me Leucothoe, cure the wound
Thine eyes hath made, pity a begging King,
Uncharm the charms of thy bewitching face,
Or thou wilt leave me dead: will nothing move thee,
Thou art a witch, a traitor, thou hast sought
By unresisted spells thy sovereign's life:
Who are about us there, call in the lords again,
Lord Polemetes, take your daughter to you,
Keep her at home.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I will my liege, Rosio see her there I wonder what is done.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Euphues I have ta'en a solemn oath
Never to grant a pardon to thy son.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: O say not so my liege, your grace I know
Has mercy for a greater fault than this.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My oath is past and cannot be recalled.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: This is beyond our wishes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: What made him swear this I wonder.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: A heavy oath to me and most unlooked for,
Your justice sir has set the period
Unto a loyal house, a family
That have been props of the Sicylian crown,
that with their bloods in many an honoured field,
'Gainst the hot French, and neopolitan
Have served for you and your great ancestors,
Their children now can never more do so,
Farewell my sovereign, whilst I in tears
Spend the sad remnant of my childless age,
I'll pray for your long life and happy reign,
And may your grace and your posterity
At need find hands as good and hearts as true
As ours have ever been.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Farewell good old man.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: For you my lord, your cruelty has deserved
A curse from me, but I can utter none,
Your daughter's goodness has weighed down your malice
Heaven prosper her.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He is an honest man and truly noble,
O my rash oath, my lust, that was the cause,
Would any price would buy it in again.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: Your majesty is just.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: 'Tis a happy land
Where the King squares his actions by the law.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, you are base and bloody,
That feeds your malice with pretence of justice,
'Tis such as you make princes tyrannous,
And hated of their subjects, but look to't,
Look your own heads stands fast for if the law
Do find a hole in your coats, beg no mercy.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Pardon us my lord, we were wronged.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And sought redress but by a lawful course.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well leave me alone.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Fare well my liege, now let him chafe alone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Now we have our ends.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is there no means to save him no way,
To get a dispensation for an oath,
None that I know except the court of Rome
Will grant one, that's well thought on,
I will not spare for gold, and that will do it,
Nicanor.

sp.speaker: Nica.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What book is that
thou hadst from Paris about the price of sins.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis called the texes of the apostolical chancery.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Is there a price for any sin set down.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: A my sir, how heinous ere it be,
Or of what nature, for such a sum of money
As is set down there, it shall be remitted

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: That's well, go fetch the book presently.Exit Nic.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sure there is perjury
Among the rest, and I shall know what rate
It bears before I have committed it.
How now hast brought it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Read, I would know the price of perjury,

sp.speaker: Nic
sp.p: I shall find it quickly, here's an index.He readsimp. For murder of all kinds of a clergy man, of a lay man, of father, mother, son, brother, sister, wife.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: Read till you come at perjury.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Item, for empoisoning, enchantments, witchcraft,
Sacrilege, simony, and their kind and
Branches. Item, pro lapsu carnis, fornication
Adultery, incest without any exception or
Distinction; for sodomy, brutality, or any of
That kind.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My heart shakes with horror
To hear the names of such detested sins,
Can these be bought for any price of money,
Or do these merchants but deceive the world
With their false wares ▪ no more of that foul book,
I will know what I came to know,
I would not for the world redeem my oath
By such a course as this, no more Nicanor
Unless thou find a price for atheism.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Here's none for that my lord, his holiness
Can pardon that in no man but himself.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Well this is not the way,
