I have thought of another that may prove,
And both discharge my oath and save his life,
Nicanor run presently, call Matho hither,
Matho the lawyer, command him to make haste,
I long to be resolved.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I run sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He is a subtle lawyer, and may find
Some point, that in the law's obscurity
He's hid from us, some point may do us good,
I have seen some of his profession
Out of case as plain, as clear as day
To our weak judgements, and no doubt at first
Meant like our thoughts by those that made the law,
Pick out such hard inextricable doubts,
That they have spun a suit of seven year long,
And lead their hood wink clients in a wood,
A most irremovable labyrinth,
Till they have quite consumed 'em, this they can do
In other cases, why not as well in this.
I have seen others could extend the law
Upon the wrack, or cut it short again
To their own private profits, as that thief
Cruel Procrustes served his hapless guests,
To fit them to his bed; well I shall see,
I would Nicanor were returned again,
I would fain ease my conscience of that oath,
That rash and inconsiderate oath I took,
But see, here they are coming. Enter Matho.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Health to my sovereign.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Matho, welcome.
I sent for thee about a business
I would entreat thy help in.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your highness may command my service
In that, or any thing lies in my power.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis to decide a case that troubles me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If it lie within the compass of my knowledge,
I will resolve your highness presently.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then thus it is, lord Euphues son,
Young Philocles, has lately stolen away
The daughter and heir of lord Polimetes,
Who is his enemy, he following him hard
Has apprehended him, and brings him to his trial
tomorrow morning: thou hast heard this news.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I have my liege, and every circumstance
That can be thought on in the business.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And what will be the issue by the law.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: He must die for it, the case is plain,
Unless your grace will grant his pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: But can there be no means thought upon
To save him by the law.

sp.speaker: Matho.
sp.p: None my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Surely there may, speak man, I'll give thee
Double fees.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: It cannot be my liege, the statutes is plain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nay now thou art too honest, thou shouldst do
As other lawyers do, first take my money,
And then tell me thou canst do me good.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I dare not undertake it, could it be done,
I'd go as far as any man would do.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes if 'twere to cut a poor man's throat you could,
For some rich griping landlord you could grinned
The face of his poor tenant, stretch the law
To serve his turn, and guided by his angels,
Speak oracles more than the tongues of men,
Than you could find exceptions, reservations,
Stand at a word, a syllable, a letter,
Or coin some scruples out of your own brains,
But in a cause so full of equity
So charitable as this, you can find nothing,
I shall for ever hate all your profession.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I do beseech your highness to excuse me,
I cannot do more than your laws will let me,
Nor falsify my knowledge nor my conscience.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then I am miserable, rise Matho rise,
I do not discommend thy honesty,
But blame my own hard fate, ay Philocles
I would redeem thy life at any price,
But the stars cross it, cruel fate condemns thee.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Come fellow watchmen, for now you are my fellows,

sp.speaker: Watchman
sp.p: It pleases you to call us so master constable.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I do it to encourage you in your office, it is a trick that we commanders have, your great captains call your soldier's fellow soldiers to encourage them.

sp.speaker: 2. watchman
sp.p: Indeed and so they do, I heard master curate trading a story book tother day to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Well I must show now what you have to do, for I myself before I came to this prefermity, was as simple as one of you, and for your better destruction, I will deride my speech into two parts. First, what is a watchman. Secondly, what is the office of a watchman. For the first, if any man ask me what is a watchman, I may answer him, he is a man as others are, nay a tradesman, as a vintner, a tailor, or the like, for they have long bills.

sp.speaker: ●. Wat.
sp.p: He tells us true neighbour, we have bills indeed.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: For the second, what is his office; I answer, he may by virtue of his office reprehend any person, or persons, that walk the streets too late at a seasonable hour.

sp.speaker: 4. Wat
sp.p: May we indeed master constable.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Nay, if you meet any of those rogues at seasonable hours, you may by virtue of your office commit him to prison, and then ask him whither he was going.

sp.speaker: ●. watchman
sp.p: Why that's as much as my lord mayor does.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: True, my lord maior can do no more than you in that point.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p: But master constable what if he should resist us.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Why if he do resist, you may knock him down, and then bid him stand, and come afore the constable. So 〈…〉 you are sufficiently constructed concerning you office take your stands, you shall hear rogues walking at these seasonable hours, I warrant you, stand close.

sp.l: Purpose, now do I take as much care to be apprehended,
As others do to scape the watch, I must speak
To be overheard, and plainly too, or else these dolts
Will never conceive me.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Hark who goes by?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: O my conscience, my conscience, the terror of a guilty conscience.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: How, conscience talks he of,
He's an honest man, I warrant him, let him pass

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.p: I ay, let him pass, good night honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: These are wise officers, I must be plainer yet.
That gold, that cursed gold, that made me poison him
Made me poison Eugenio.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: How made me poison him, he's a knave I warrant him.

sp.speaker: 3. Wa.
sp.l: M. Constable has found him already,

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I warrant you a knave cannot pass me, go reprehend him, I'll take his excommunication myself.

sp.speaker: 1. Wa.
sp.l: Come afore the constable

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.p: Come afore the constable.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah, you would have scaped
Would you, no sirrah you shall know the King's
Officers have eyes to hear such rogues as you,
Come sirrah, confess who it was you poisoned, he
Looks like a notable rogue.

sp.speaker: 1. Wa.
sp.l: I do not like
His looks.

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: You would deny it
Would you sirrah, we shall sift you,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Alas master

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: I cannot now deny what I have said
You over heard me, I poisoned Eugenio son to
Lord Polimetes.

sp.speaker: 1. Wa.
sp.p: O rascal.

sp.speaker: 2. Wa.
sp.l: My
Young landlord.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Let him alone, the law
Shall punish him, but sirrah where did you poison
Him.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: About a day's journey hence, as he was
Coming home from Athens I met him, and
Poisoned him.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: But sirrah who set you a work
Confess, I shall find out the whole nest of their
Rogues, speak.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Count Virro hired me to do it.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: O lying rascal.

sp.speaker: 1. Wat.
sp.p: Nay he that will steal will lie.

sp.speaker: 2. Wat.
sp.p: I'll believe nothing he says.

sp.speaker: 3. Wat.
sp.p: Be lie a man of worship.

sp.speaker: 4. Wat.
sp.l: A noble man

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Away with him, I'll hear no more, remit him to
Prison; sirrah, you shall hear of these things
Tomorrow, where you would be loath to hear 'em.
Come let's go.Exeunt.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Franklin, shallow, Luce, Francisco in a parson's habit, and a true parson otherwise attired.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I'll take your counsel sir, I'll not be seen in't, but meet you when 'tis done, you'll marry them.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fear not that sir, I'll do the deed.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: I shall rest thankful to you, till then I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.p: I pray father leave us, we know how to behave ourselves alone, methinks Luce we are too many by two yet.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: You are merry sir.Exeunt manet Franklin.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Now they are sure or never, poor Francisco
Thou metst thy match, when thou durst undertake
To overreach me with tricks, where's now your sumner?
Fore heaven I cannot but applaud my brain,
To take my daughter even against her will,
And great with child by another, her shame published,
She cited to the court, and yet bestow her
On such a fortune as rich shallow is,
Nay that which is the masterpiece of all,
Make him believe 'tis his, though he ne'er touched her,
If men never met with crosses in the world,
There were no difference twixt the wise and fools,
But I'll go meet 'em, when 'tis done, I fear not.Exit.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Nay fret not now, you have been worse abused
if you had married her, she never loved you.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: I ever scorned thy folly and hated thee, though
Sometimes afore my father I would make an ass
Of thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: O women, monstrous women,
Little does her father know who has married her.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.l: Yes, he knows the parson married me,
And you can witness that.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And he shall know the parson will lie with her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Well parson, I will be revenged on all thy coat,
I will not plough an acre of ground for you to
Tithe, I'll rather pasture my neighbour's cattle
For nothing.

sp.speaker: Parson
sp.p: O be more charitable sir, bid God give 'em joy.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I care not greatly if I do, he is not the first
Parson that has taken a gentleman's leavings.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How mean you sir?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: You guess my meaning, I hope to have good luck
To horseflesh now she is a parson's wife.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have lain with her then sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I cannot tell you that, but if you saw a woman with child without lying with a man, than perhaps I have not.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Impudent coxcomb, darest thou say that ever thou layst with me, didst thou ever so much as kiss my hand in private.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: These things must not be spoken of in company.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: Thou knowest I ever hated thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: But when you were i'th good humour you would tell me another tale.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: The fool is mad, by heaven my Francisco I am wronged. He discovers himself.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Then I must change my note, sirrah, unsay
What you have spoken, swear here before
The parson and myself, you never touched her, or
I'll cut thy throat, it is Francisco threatens thee.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: I am in a sweet case, what should I do now, her
Father thinks I have lain with her, if I deny it
He'll have about with me, if I say I have, this
Young rogue will cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come will you swear.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I would I were fairly off, I would lose my wench with all my heart, I swear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So, now thou art free from any imputation that his tongue can stick upon thee.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Well now I see 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Here's one
Shall 〈◊〉 with you.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: God give you joy son

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I thank you father.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: How's this, Francisco in the parson's habit,

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: I have married her as you bade me sir, but this
Was the truer parson of the two, he tied the
Knot and this gentleman is our witness ▪

sp.p: 〈…〉 undone, strumpet thou hast betrayed thy 〈…〉 beggary, to shame besides, and that in open court, 〈…〉 what thou hast sought, hang, beg, and starve, I'll 〈…〉.
Good sir.

sp.speaker: S●●l..
sp.p: I told you what would come on't.
How did your wisdom lose her?
〈…〉 you see ▪ I was beguiled, and so were you.
〈◊〉 take her, thou seest the portion thou art like to have.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Tis such a portion as will ever please 〈…〉 for her sake be not unnatural.
Do not reject me father.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But for the fault 〈…〉 were for, or shame she should endure in 〈◊〉, behold her yet an untouched virgin, cushion come 〈…〉 shallow, take your child unto you, make 〈…〉 prove as wise as the father.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.l: This is more strange than tother, ah Luce, we●●
〈◊〉 so subtle to deceive thyself, and me; well
〈…〉, 'tis thine own choice.

sp.p: Sir we can force no bounty from you, and there●●●● must rest content with what your pleasure is.

〈…〉 he is my lord, that's he in the parsons 〈…〉 thus disguised about the business I told you of
Lysandro, see your noble father.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Welcome my long lost son from all the storms
Of frowning fortune that thou hast endured
Into thy father's arms.

sp.speaker: Luce.
sp.p: I● my Francisco noble.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.p: Lord Euphues son, I am amazed.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.p: I hear Lysandro that you are married.

sp.speaker: Francisco.
sp.p: Yes my lord, this is my bride, the daughter and heir of this rich gentleman, 'twas only she that when my state was nothing, my poor self and parentage unknown, vouchsafed to know, nay grace me with her love, her constant love.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Such merit must not be forgotten my son,
Daughter much joy attend upon your choice.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Now wants but your consent.

sp.speaker: Frank.
sp.l: Which with a willing heart I do bestow,
Pardon me worthy son, I have so long
Been hard to you, 'twas ignorance
Of what you were, and care I took for her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your care needs no apology.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: But now Lysandro I must make thee sad
Upon thy wedding day, and let thee know
There is no pure and uncompounded joy
Lent to 〈◊〉, in depth of woe
Thou 〈◊〉 the knowledge of thy parentage,
Thy elder 〈…〉 Philocles must die,
And 〈…〉, our name and house
Had 〈…〉 ever, had not gracious heaven
Sent as a courtier to my childless age,
Thy long lost self supporter of the name.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.p: But can there be no means to save his life.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: 〈…〉 none, the King has ta'en an oath
Never to 〈◊〉 him, but since they say
His majesty repents, and fain would save him.

sp.speaker: Franc,
sp.l: Then up I wretched, like a man long blind,
That comes at last to see the wished for son,
But find it in eclipse, such is my case,
To meet in this dark woe my dearest friends,

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Had you not heard this news before Lysandro?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yes sir, and did lament,
As for a worthy stranger, but ne'er knew
My sorrow stood engaged by such a tie
As brotherhood, where may we see him sir?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: This morning he's arraigned, put of that habit
You are in, and go along with me, leave your
Friends hear awhile.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell father,
Dear luce till soon farewell, naught but so sad
A chance, could make me cloudy now.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Frank:
sp.l: Well Luce thy choice has proved better than we
Expected, but this cloud of grief has dimmed
Our mirth, but will I hope blow over,
Heaven grant it may.
And signior shallow, though you have missed what
My love meant you once, pray be my guest.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I thank you sir, I'll not be strange.Exeunt

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nicanor, I would find some privy place
Where I might stand unseen, unknown of any,
To hear the arraignment of young Philocles.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: The judges are now entering, please you sir
Here to ascend, you may both hear and see.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Well I'll go up,
And like a jealous husband here and see
That that will strike me dead, am I a King
And cannot pardon such a small offence,
I cannot do't, nor am I Caesar now,
Lust has uncrowned me, and my rash ta'e oath
H●s' 〈◊〉 of a King's prerogative,
Come come Nicanor, help me to ascend,
And ●ee that fault that I want power to mend.Ascendant

div.stage: Enter ▪ judges, Virro, Polimetes, Euphues, Francisco, Leucothoe, Clerimont, Roscio.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.p: Bring forth the prisoner, where are the witnesses?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here my lords, I am the wronged party,
And the fact my man, here besides the officers
that took them can justify.

sp.speaker: 2. Judge
sp.p: That's enough.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: Philocles stand to the bar, and answer to such
Crimes as shall be here objected against thy life.
Read the enditement.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Spare that labour,
I do confess the fact that I am charged with,
And speak as much as my accusers can,
As much as all the witnesses can prove,
'Twas I that stole away the daughter and heir
Of the lord Polimetes, which wert to do again
Rather than lose her, I again would venture,
This was the fact, your sentence honoured fathers.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: 'Tis brave and resolute.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: A heavy sentence noble Philocles,
And such a one, as I could wish myself
Off from this place, some other might deliver,
You must die for it, death is your sentence.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Which I embrace with willingness, now my lord,To Pol.
Is your hate glutted yet, or is my life
Too poor a sacrifice to appease the rancour
Of your inveterate malice, if it be to
Invent some scandal that may after blot
My reputation, father dry your tears,
Weep not for me, my death shall leave no stain
Upon your blood, nor blot on your fair name ▪
The honoured ashes of my ancestors
May still rest quiet in their tear wet urns
For any fact of mine, I might have lived
If heaven had not prevented it, and found
Death for some foul dishonourable act.
Brother farewell, no sooner have I foundTo Francisco
But I must leave thy wished for company.
Farewell my dearest love, live thou still happy,
And may some one of more desert than I,
Be blessed in the enjoying what I lose,
I need not wish him happiness that has thee,
for 〈…〉 bring it may he prove as good
〈…〉 worthy.
Dearest Philocles,
〈…〉 for any man but thee
〈…〉 good my lords
〈…〉 both together
〈…〉 alike, why should the law
〈…〉 and lay it all on him,
〈…〉 would we could as lawfully
〈…〉 he should not die for this,
〈…〉, who's that you have brought there?
〈…〉 a benefactor, if it please your lordships,
〈…〉 him in my watch last night.

sp.p: What's his offence?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Murder.
No master constable, 'twas but poisoning of a man.
〈…〉 a fool.
〈…〉 for ever, all will out.
What proofs have you against him?
His own profession if it please your honour.

sp.l: And 〈…〉 ill profession, to be a murderer, thou
〈…〉 has confessed the fact.

sp.p: Yes my lord, he cannot deny it.
Did he not name the party who it was that he had 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Marry with reverence be it spoken.
〈…〉 my lord Polimetes his son.
How's this

sp.speaker: 1. ju
sp.p: He died long sense at Athens.

sp.l: I cannot tell what I should think of it,
〈…〉 the man that lately brought me news
〈…〉 to the bar, thou hearest thy accusation
〈…〉 say.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Ah my good lord,
〈…〉 deny what I have said,
〈…〉, as my bleeding heart
Was making confession of my crime.

sp.speaker: C●n.
sp.l: I told him an● shall please your lordship's
〈…〉 King's officers had eyes to hear such rascals.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: You have been careful in your office constable,
You may now leave your prisoner,

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I'll leave the fell on with your lordship.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: Farewell good

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Murder I see will out.Exit Con.
Why didst thou poison him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I was poor,
And want made me be hired.

sp.speaker: 2. Judge
sp.p: Hired, by whom?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: By count Virro,
There he stands.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I do beseech your lordships not to credit
What this base fellow speaks, I am innocent.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: I do believe you are, sirrah speak truth,
You have not long to live.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Please it your lordship
I may relate the manner.

sp.speaker: 3. Judge
sp.p: Do.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Eugenio was alive when first the news
Was spread in Syracuse he was dead,
Which false report count Virro crediting,
Became an earnest suitor to his sister
Thinking her heir, but finding afterwards
Her brother lived, and coming home
Not a day's journey hence, he sent me to him,
And with a promise of five hundred crowns
Hired me to poison him, that this is true
Here's his own hand to witness it against him,
Please it your lordships to peruse the writing.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.p: This is his hand.

sp.speaker: 2. Judge
sp.l: Sure as I live,
I have seen warrants from him with just these
Characters.

sp.speaker: 3. Judge
sp.l: Besides methinks this fellow's
Tale is likely.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: 'Tis too true,
This fellows sudden going from my house
Put me into a fear.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: Count Virro, stand to the bar,
What can you say to clear you of this murder?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: Nothing my lords, I must confess the fact.

sp.speaker: 2. Judge
sp.l: Why then against you both do I pronounce.
Sentence of death.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: The law is just.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Wretch that I am, is my dissembled grief
Turned to true sorrow, were my acted tears
but prophecies of my ensuing woe,
And is he truly dead. o pardon me
De●ie ghost of my Eugenio, 'twas my fault
That called this hasty vengeance from the gods,
And shortened thus thy life, for whilst with tricks
Brought to fasten wealth upon our house,
Thought a cannibal to be the grave
Of me and mine, base bloody murderous count.

sp.speaker: V●r..
sp.p: Vile cozener, cheating lord, dissembler.

sp.speaker: ●. Judge
sp.l: Peace, stop the mouth of malediction there,
This is no place to rail in.
Ye just powers,
That to the quality of man's offence,
●●●pe your correcting rods, and punish there
Where he has sinned, did not my bleeding heart
〈◊〉 such a heavy share in this day's woe,
Woes could with a free soul applaud your justice.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Lord Euphues and Philocles forgive me
To make amends, I know's impossible
For what my malice wrought, but I would fain
〈…〉 that might testify my grief
〈…〉 Repentance.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: This is that I looked for.

sp.l: You're kind too late my lord, had you been thus
〈…〉 required, y'had saved yourself and me,
〈…〉 sons, but if your grief be true
〈…〉 you heartily.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And I,
Now comes my que, my lord Polimetes,
〈…〉 correction let me ask one question.

sp.p: What question? speak.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If this young lord
〈…〉, would you bestow your daughter
〈…〉 upon him, would you lord?

sp.p: As willingly as I would breathe myself.

sp.l: Then dry all your eyes,
〈…〉 hear shall have a cause to week,To Phil.
〈…〉, Leucothoe is no heir,
〈…〉 lives, and that clears you count Virro
〈…〉 Murder.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How, lives?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Yes lives to call thee brother Philocles.

sp.speaker: Leu.
sp.p: O my dear brother.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My son,
Welcome from death.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Pardon me good my lord that I thus long
Have from your knowledge kept myself concealed,
My end was honest.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I see 'twas,
And now son Philocles give me thy hand,
Here take thy wife, she loves thee I dare swear,
And for the wrong that I intended thee,
Her portion shall be double what I meant it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I thank your lordship.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Brother Euphues,
I hope all enmity is now forgotten
Betwixt our houses.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Let it be ever so, I do embrace your love.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Well my life is saved yet, though my wench be lost,
God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Thanks good my lord.

sp.speaker: 1. Judge
sp.l: How suddenly this tragic scene is charged,
And turned to comedy

sp.speaker: 2. Judge
sp.p: 'Tis very strange. The King speaks from 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Let us conclude within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay,
And take my joy with you.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: His majesty
Is coming down, let us attend. Enter King.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: These jars are well closed up, now Philocles,
What my rash oath denied me, this blessed how●e
And happy accident has brought to pass,
The saving of thy life.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A life my liege,
That shall be ever ready to be spent
Upon your service.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thanks good Philocles,
But where's the man whose happy presence brought
All this unlooked for sport: where is Eugenio?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Here my dread liege.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome to 〈…〉
Welcome Eugenio, prithee ask some boon
That may requite the good that thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I thank your majesty, what I have done
Needs no requital, but I have a suit
Unto lord Euphues, please it your majesty
To be to him an intercessor for me,
I make no question but I shall obtain.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What is it? speak, it shall be granted thee.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: That it would please him to bestow on me
His niece, the fair and virtuous lady Leda.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: With all my heart, I know 'twill please her well,
I have often heard her praise Eugenio,
It shall be done within.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then here all strife ends,
I'll be your guest myself today, and help
To solemnize this double marriage.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Your royal presence shall much honour us.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Then lead away, the happy knot you tie,
Concludes in love two houses enmity.

div.head: Epilogus.
div.l: Our author's heir if it be legitimate
'Tis his, if not, he dares the worst of fate,
For if a bastard, charity is such,
That what you give, it cannot be too much,
And he, and we, vow if it may be shown,
To do as much for yours, as for our own.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
